subtitle: [Music]
Thinking Allowed.
Conversations on the leading edge of
knowledge and discovery
with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
I'm here to
interview one of my favorite New
Thinking Allowed
guests. That's me.
Myself. And today we're going to talk
about space,
time and consciousness. It's really a
profound question. It's one that's puzzled me for years
and years. I couldn't think of a
better person to
discuss it with and the reason is
this. As a parapsychologist I've often
been puzzled by the fact that
extrasensory perception seems to defy
all conventional scientific explanation,
in the sense that there's no
organ of perception, there's no
means of transmission of
information across space and time, and
yet people seem to have knowledge of distant events and
future events. So I'd often
thought that space and time
are not really what we assume them
to be. Today,
I think we can begin to probe that a
little further. Let me begin
by asking you, my guest,
what do you think of space and time at
this point?
Interesting that you say “at this point,”
because this is a point
in space and time. You could say this is
a point in the evolution of this
particular biological organism having a conversation with
itself about space and time.
But of course our topic is space, time
and consciousness. I think it's fair
to say, as has really been discussed on
many New Thinking Allowed interviews,
that space and time, all of space and
time, to the very distant reaches of the
universe, you might even say infinity,
you might say infinity in terms of
the past, infinity in terms of the future,
infinity in terms of how far away in
space we can go — all of that exists within consciousness.
By that I mean within
my personal consciousness. But let me be
clear. I don't mean ego
by personal, I mean self. And
when I say self I'm referring to, in
kind of a Jungian sense, by which I mean,
as my friend Bernardo Kastrup loves to
quote Schopenhauer: “The one eye that looks out through the
eyes of every living creature.” That is to
say, the one consciousness
that looks out through the eyes of every
living creature. Well, since you have
brought up the psychology of Carl Jung it's probably worth mentioning that
Jung speaks of the collective
unconscious.
I think it's fair to say, even for
myself, yourself, that
when you talk about that one
consciousness, that consciousness that encompasses the entire
universe, it's rarely that at the
personal level you're aware of it. Because let's face it, you,
like every other person from day to day
you're concerned with
practical concerns, when are you going to
eat, what are you going to eat,
what are you going to do today to earn a
living? Of course, that's all true
for me and for all of our viewers
as well. Here we are dealing with our
biological forms and
the biological form pretty much
keeps us grounded within
space and time. In fact, it's such
a tenacious illusion that we tend to
think that space and time exists independently of our own
consciousness. In fact,
for most of my life I'd say it seemed
pretty obvious to me
that I measure space according to
rulers and miles and airplane
destinations, and I measure time in terms
of what the clock tells
me. All of these things are outside of
myself. They're not
part of my consciousness.
And yet, isn't it the case that some
of the great
philosophers, perhaps Immanuel Kant, one
of the greatest of all philosophers, made it very clear
that these categories that seem
so a priori before
anything human, something that we see
outside of ourselves: No, he said, these
categories are the result
of being conscious. How can that be
though? They seem so independent of
each person. After all, when you look at
the life
of any given human being you have a
birthday,
a date of birth and a date of death, a
date of marriage, a date of confirmation or bar mitzvah
or bat mitzvah. It seems as if
the organism itself is defined
by space and time. Yes, but if you look at
physics itself, which is the study
of the physical universe, everything in
space and time,
what does it boil down to? We have these
particles and they are so tiny and so distant from each other
that it's mostly all vacuum and yet it
seems so solid to us.
And yet also the physicists
are telling us that at the quantum level
time can easily be reversed,
there's no necessity for time to flow only in one direction.
All of that occurs at what we think of
as the macro
level. And the macro level is completely
dependent upon
the way we perceive it through our
sensory organs.
If it wasn't for these sensory organs we
might be traveling along on a light beam.
Well, in fact, it was traveling on a light
beam. That was the thought experiment
that Albert Einstein engaged in that led
to his
development of the Theory of Relativity:
What would it be like to travel on a light beam? And it seems as if
in the example of Einstein, consciousness
has that property, consciousness can
travel on a light beam. Einstein
showed that. In fact, consciousness can do
a great deal more than that.
Look at all of the work in remote
viewing. It's showing that it doesn't work perfectly yet,
after all we are still biological
organisms. But
in consciousness people
using remote viewing can travel to
distant locations in time and space
and come up with accurate descriptions
of what they experience. And in
consciousness people can do many, many
other things. There are yogis
who can bilocate. There are a whole
category of people who report
out-of-body experiences. Many people have,
and in particular J.H.
M. Whiteman, otherwise known as Michael
Whiteman, has demonstrated over decades in great detail in his writings the ability to
leave his body at will
and travel across these other dimensions,
dimensions that
we could consider part of the collective
unconscious
perhaps. Or perhaps, as my friend Ruth
Kastner points out in the interview that was just released
two days before this one will be
released, into the area
of possibility, quantum
probabilities, the Schrodinger psi waves,
the realm
in which anything might happen. How
fascinating that you bring up
Schrodinger psi waves. I know many, many
years ago in a book called,
if I remember correctly, The Scientist
Speculates edited by I.J. Good, it's
probably half a century old or more. I think it was I.J.
Good himself, the mathematician, who
suggested that
the psi of the Schrodinger psi waves
and the psi of parapsychology
were really the same psi. That is, that
ability of the mind to access
information from distant points in time
and space
is the equivalent of the
probability waves of quantum mechanics.
I think my friend
Stuart Hameroff when speaking about
consciousness at the quantum level
refers to that level as quantum geometry.
Ruth Kastner, in the recently released
interview with her, talks about it as
the realm of possibility. In fact, she says the reality
of possibility, it's an ontologically
real level
but it is not part of space-time.
Actually space-time
emerges from it. And
it's worth mentioning that our good
friend Bernardo
Kastrup, the brilliant philosopher, the
champion of what he calls
analytical idealism, the philosophy
in alignment with Kant and Schopenhauer
and Barkley, that the universe itself is
essentially mental in nature, that
it's not just dead matter, it's
consciousness, the one
consciousness that sees through the eyes
of every living creature.
That's what we're talking about
when we talk about the
reality of possibility or the reality of
probability,
it's consciousness itself. And that
consciousness has within it realms within realms within
realms. The interesting thing is that
these realms have been mapped out by
consciousness explorers, by the ancient
yogis, by people engaged in out-of-body experience, by
modern meditators, by remote viewers, even
by people such as Frederick Myers, the
great psychical researcher who dictated, apparently, books from the afterlife
about what that afterlife realm is all
about.
Not to mention the explorations of
psychologists such as Carl Jung using
active imagination.
It's as if there's a whole other
continent, a continent of
infinite possibilities, yet we can map it.
What an exciting idea. Now, I know
we've looked at that before, we've
discussed it with for example, Charles Tart, one of my
dissertation committee members when I
was a graduate student
at Berkeley, who back in 1973
in Science magazine published an article
called,
“State Specific Science,” can we go into
altered states of consciousness
and in those states begin to measure new
aspects of reality that
are only accessible to us when we're in
those states?
Well, as I recall from my recent
discussions with Charlie
Tart about that he was rather pessimistic,
in the sense that he felt that
any such exploration would always be
conditioned by or clouded by or tainted
by the sociological preconceptions of people. If you're a Buddhist,
you're going into that exploration with
a cosmology already in mind. If you're a Christian, you have a different
cosmology already in mind. And so
your exploration of these mental realms
is going to be conditioned by your own
mentality, and there's no getting around
it. That indeed is a serious problem. But I wouldn't say that it's necessarily
a problem that can't be overcome. It may
take time, it may take another hundred
years, but the point is that the problem
has been recognized. How do we get
outside of our own mentality
when we are exploring realms of
consciousness itself?
Funny you should mention that. I recently
came across
an interesting book by a person I've
known of for many years,
Angela Brown Miller. She's a
psychologist who works in the areas of
addiction but her book is a fascinating book and I plan to have
another conversation with her about it
in the future,
How to Die and Survive.
It is about letting go, it's about
the process of
letting go of everything to which you're
attached,
your identity, your sense of self,
your mentality. And after you've let go
of your mentality
completely you still are left with pure
awareness. It is from that state
of pure awareness that you can
begin to explore these realms, these
subtle realms of consciousness.
It's like a new continent. Imagine
in the 1500s, in the 1400s even,
the European explorers were just
discovering the new world.
We're in a similar position right now.
We're just discovering the new world. But
as Pogo says,
we have met the enemy and it is us.
It is certainly a challenging exploration.
It's an exploration that would include
of course
the archetypes of the Jungian
subconscious mind, the Freudian
subconscious mind.
It would include the bardo planes that
are referred to in Tibetan Buddhism, the
realms
of the afterlife. Jung is quite
clear that those realms, afterlife realms, are part of
the collective unconscious. But beyond
that it would include
realms that have been explored by
pioneers such as Whitley Strieber,
talking about “the visitors,” aliens who
come to this planet from
other locations, other dimensions perhaps
in space, hyperspace perhaps,
perhaps from other planets. We know that
there's a
great deal of exploration going on there
and there's
much to be said about the relationship
between the visitors from other planets and other dimensions
and the realm of the afterlife. We could
have to assume if we're talking about
the one consciousness that sees through
the eyes of
all creatures that that includes
many kinds of creatures beyond the vast
variety we know of
already, biological creatures, of this
earth, that there are even realms beyond that. So the
exploration to be considered is
just enormous and really it is just
beginning. There are certainly many
obstacles, the biggest obstacle being
obviously ourselves, our conditioning, our mentality. But, let us begin.
It's not as if we can't solve
some of these problems. And I think
that's a good note to end on,
so let me thank you very much for
interviewing me about this most
vital of all topics. And for those of you
watching, thank you for being with us.
[Music]
